docs.lead_paragraph: Let us pause today to consider the travails of Jane Swift, the lieutenant governor of Massachusetts, who has gotten into very hot water for using her Statehouse aides as sitters for her baby daughter. Ms. Swift made news last year by running for office while she was in an advanced state of pregnancy -- baby Elizabeth, now 14 months, was born two weeks before the election. There was a bit of carping from social conservatives who felt she should have dropped out and stayed home.

headline.main: Public Interests; A Mommy Track Derails

docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column on flap over Massachusetts Lt Gov Jane Swift's use of Statehouse aides as baby sitters; questions her defense of practice in light of her role as sort of ethics spokeswoman for state's current Republican administration (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Rae Carruth, facing murder and conspiracy charges, appeared in court in Charlotte, N.C., yesterday on a new charge that he violated a state anti-abortion law by trying to kill his unborn child. The former Carolina Panthers wide receiver told Judge Jerome Leonard at the hearing that he understood the charge. He is to appear in court again Feb. 8.
docs.abstract: Rae Carruth, facing murder and conspiracy charges in connection with slaying of girlfriend Cherica Adams, is charged with violating North Carolina's anti-abortion law by trying to kill his unborn child (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton said today that he would urge Congress to reverse course on a law that he reluctantly signed just months ago that bans United States money from going to international organizations that perform abortions or promote abortion rights. Congressional Republicans insisted on the abortion language as part of a spending package eagerly sought by the administration to free nearly $1 billion that the United States owed to the United Nations.

headline.main: Clinton Wants to End Limits On Family Planning Funds

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton says he will urge Congress to reverse course on law he reluctantly signed months ago that bans United States money from going to international family planning services that provide abortions or promote abortion rights; Clinton's signing of bill drew wrath of abortion rights advocates; Congressional Republicans had insisted on abortion language as part of spending package that also freed $1 billion that United States owed to United Nations, something eagerly sought by White House (M)
docs.snippet: President Clinton said today that he would urge Congress to reverse course on a law that he reluctantly signed just months ago that bans United States money from going to international organizations that perform abortions or promote abortion rights. ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials, health workers and nightclub owners have been arguing for months over developing a municipal policy to get the denizens of the freewheeling night life mecca here to obtain and use condoms. On Monday, the West Hollywood City Council approved a plan to give 320,000 free condoms this year to 33 gay bars, which would voluntarily supply the condoms to their clientele. But, feeling the step insufficient, the AIDS Healthcare Foundation, which treats 5,000 patients throughout the Los Angeles area, has proposed a competing initiative that would ask West Hollywood voters to make the program apply to all bars in the city and would require participation.

headline.main: City Debates Two Proposals On Condoms

docs.abstract: Officials, health workers and nighclub owners in West Hollywood, Calif, are arguing over municipal policy to get denizens of freewheeling nightlife mecca there to obtain and use condoms; City Council approved plan to give 320,000 free condoms to 33 gay bars, which would voluntarily supply condoms to clientele; AIDS Healthcare Foundation proposes competing initiative that would ask West Hollywood voters to make program apply to all bars in city and would require participation; toughest opponents may be bar patrons themselves, many of whom are skeptical of government sponsorhip of such programs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The dietary supplement industry, freed from strict regulation by the 1994 Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act, has made a vast variety of herbal remedies as readily available on supermarket shelves as ordinary vitamins. Millions of consumers now take supplements, like ginkgo, kava and St. John's wort, that were largely unknown in mainstream markets even a few years ago. Although some research suggests that some supplements can produce positive health effects, there have also been cases where people have been made ill by supplements, or their conditions have become worse while they tried to use ineffective dietary supplements to treat a medical disease. Despite explosive growth in this industry, there is very little guidance or protection afforded to consumers. The 1994 act severely limited the ability of the Food and Drug Administration to police supplements for safety and effectiveness. Now the F.D.A. has made this situation worse. It will allow supplement makers to make even broader marketing claims about their products under regulations that go into effect next month.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges Congress to give Food and Drug Administration greater authority to regulate dietary supplement industry

docs.lead_paragraph: A day after an aggressive and sometimes vitriolic encounter in New Hampshire, the six Republican presidential candidates went easier on one another in debate tonight, this time turning much of their fire on President Clinton and the Democratic candidates for president. In a conservative state with a large military presence, many of the Republicans lashed into Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley for saying they would allow gays to serve in the military.

headline.main: G.O.P. Candidates Redirect Their Fire Toward Democrats

docs.abstract: Republican presidential candidates hold second debate in 24 hours, West Columbia, SC; candidates, Gov George W Bush, Sens John McCain and Orrin G Hatch, Alan Keyes, Gary L Bauer and Steve Forbes, turn much of their fire on Pres Clinton and Democratic candidates Vice Pres Al Gore and Bill Bradley instead of each other; photos (M)
